— 'Twas midnight — every mortal eye was closed</br>Thro' the whole mansion — save an antique Crone's,</br>That o'er the dying embers faintly watch'd</br>The broken sleep (fell harbinger of Death)</br>Of a sick Boteler. — Above indeed</br>In a drear gallery (lighted by one lamp</br>Whose wick the poor departing Seneschall</br>Did closely imitate,) paced slow and sad</br>The Village Curate, waiting late to shrive</br>The Penitent when 'wake.  Scarce shewed the ray</br>To Fancy's eye the pourtrayed characters</br>That graced the wall — On this and t' other side</br>Suspended, nodded o'er the steepy stair,</br>In many a trophy formed, the knightly groupe</br>Of helms and targets, gauntlets, maces strong,</br>And horses' furniture — brave monuments</br>Of antient Chivalry — Thro' the stain'd pane</br>Low gleamed the Moon — not bright — but of such power</br>As marked the clouds, black, threatning over head,</br>Full mischief-fraught; — from these in many a peal</br>Growled the near thunder — flashed the frequent blaze</br>Of lightning blue. — While round the fretted dome</br>The wind sung surly:  with unusual clank</br>The armour shook tremendous: — On a couch</br>Plac'd in the Oriel sunk the Churchman down:</br>For who, alone, at that dread hour of night,</br>Could bear portentous prodigy?—

"I hear it," cries the proudly gilded Casque</br>(Filled by the soul of one, who erst took joy</br>In slaught'rous deeds,) "I hear amidst the gale</br>The hostile Spirit shouting — once more</br>In the thick harvest of the spears we'll shine,</br>There will be work anon." —</br>—"I'm 'wakened too,"</br>Replied the sable Helmet (tenanted</br>By a like inmate) "Hark! — I hear the voice</br>Of the impatient Ghosts, who straggling range</br>Yon summit, (crown'd with ruined battlements</br>The fruits of civil discord) to the din</br>The Spirits, wandering round this gothic pile,</br>All join their yell — the song is War and Death.—</br>There will be work anon."

—"Call armourers, Ho!</br>Furbish my vizor — close my rivets up—</br>I brook no dallying"—</br>—"Soft, my hasty friend,"</br>Said the black Beaver, "Neither of us twain</br>Shall share the bloody toil — War-worn am I,</br>Bored by a happier mace, I let in fate</br>To my once master, — since unsought, unused</br>Pensile I'm fixed — yet too your gaudy pride</br>Has nought to boast, — the fashion of the fight</br>Has thrown your gilt, and shady plumes aside</br>For modern foppery; — still do not frown,</br>Nor lour indignantly your steely brows,</br>We've comfort left enough — The bookman's lore</br>Shall trace our sometime merit; — in the eye</br>Of antiquary taste we long shall shine:</br>And as the Scholar marks our rugged front,</br>He'll say, This Cressy saw, that Agincourt:</br>Thus dwelling on the prowess of his fathers,</br>He'll venerate their Shell. — Yet, more than this,</br>From our inactive station we shall hear</br>The groans of butchered brothers, shrieking plaints</br>Of ravished maids, and matrons' frantic howls,</br>Already hovering o'er the threatened lands</br>The famish'd Raven snuffs the promised feast,</br>And hoarslier croaks for blood — 'twill flow."
—"Forbid it, Heaven!</br>O shield my suffering country! — shield it" prayed</br>The agonizing Priest.</br>
